rows.title: Unfortunately MyApp has stopped. How can I solve this?

49:
<p>First, you check which point your app has crashed (<code>Unfortunately, MyApp has stopped.</code>). For this, you can use <code>Log.e("TAG", "Message");</code>, using this line you can see your app log in logcat.</p>

<p>After that, you find which point your app has stopped it's very easy to solve at your side. </p>
<p>Check your <code>Logcat</code> message and see your <code>Manifest</code> file. There should be something missing like defining the <code>Activity,</code>User permission`, etc.</p>

<p>If your app for some reason crashes without good stacktrace. Try debug it from first line, and go line by line until crash. Then you will have answer, which line is causing you trouble. Proably you could then wrapp it into try catch block and print error output.</p>

<p>You can also get this error message on its own, without any stack trace or any further error message.</p>

<p>In this case you need to make sure your Android manifest is configured correctly (including any manifest merging happening from a library and any activity that would come from a library), and pay particular attention to the first activity displayed in your application in your manifest files.</p>

<p>First, you need to check where and why your app has been crashed <code>(Unfortunately, MyApp has stopped.).</code> With the help of <code>LOG</code>, you can figure it out what went wrong.</p>

<p>After that, you find which point your app has stopped fix that from your point.</p>
